Off Topic:

Yesterday I made mention of the word CLOTBUR, an infamous pangram that traumatized an earlier generation of Spelling Bee / Wordplay commenters. When I went to read comments from that time in 2018, I was surprised to see how often my name appeared in the Wordplay comments. I also remembered that I would occasionally compose silly poems and post them in the comments, and I knew that I had written one where CLOTBUR made an appearance. Well, I found it stored in the darkest reaches of my laptop, and thought it was still quite √† propos, so here it is.

Sung to the tune of ‚ÄúMy Favourite Things‚Äù

ENOs and ONOs and OREO cookies
ORCS, ENTS, and E-TS and ALIEN Wookies.
EEK, EKE, and ECO, and AAHs, OHS and OOHs,
These are a few of my favourite clues.

OLE ALOHA and AVE MARIA
ARIA, AREA, RIO and RIA.
LEIs LEAs and LEIAs, ALEEs and ALOUs.
These are a few of my favourite clues.


When the NAT TICKS
When the CLOT BURS
When I lose my way.
I simply remember my favourite clues 
And that's when I DOOK.

One thing I like about Michael‚Äôs puzzles is the care he puts into cluing.  It feels to me like he spends time with each answer to hit on a clue with a fresh angle.  Just as seldom-seen answers light up a grid, seldom-seen clues light up the brain.

I saw a few stock clues for inconsequential answers (OAF, ESSO, EMO, TIL) but that‚Äôs about it.  Overall, the clues brought fresh riddles, plus glints here and there of sweet wordplay.  I adored the world-class [Accrue annual leaves?] for RAKE.

So, freshness in clue, but freshness in answer as well.  Of the 12 three-stack answers in the grid, 11 have appeared in the Times puzzle but three times or less.  My favorite was the recent in-the-language PITCH CLOCK, a true debut with its first appearance in any of the major crossword outlets.

I liked the touches of beauty in WRAITH and PAEAN, and I loved the grid design, never seen before in the Times, with its whopping 16 longs.

Popping with freshness, excellence all around ‚Äì a superb outing.  Thank you so much for this, Michael!

MACAROON made my day, as it reminded me of my great-grandma Annie and great-grandpa Izzie, who introduced a very young me to this delicious treat.  There would always be a little plate of macaroons on a table in their apartment that I so looked forward to.  Grandma Annie and Grandpa Izzie filled my being with warmth, goodness, and love, and as I look back on them, they each seem surrounded by a halo.

I haven‚Äôt stopped my life and thought about them in quite a while, and MACAROON thrust me back into what it felt like to be around them, and let me tell you, going back there today melted my heart.

There were, in fact, two Greek mythological heroes named Ajax--Ajax the Telamonian and Ajax the Locrian, or Ajax the Greater and Ajax the Lesser--which doesn't seem entirely fair to Mr. Locrian, I think. "Ajax" is, of course, the Latin form--a better transliteration of the Greek is "Aias," and when the two are referred to collectively, as they sometimes are, they're termed "the Aiantes."* But only by people who use "CIT." a lot in their writing.

The clue probably refers to the former--he's the subject of an eponymous tragedy by Sophocles--after the death of Achilles, there's a dispute over who should receive the warrior's armor. Aias gets himself into a snit, and plots to murder Agamemnon, Menelaus, and Odysseus. But the gods step in, cloud his sanity, and he slaughters a couple of cattle instead (not to mention the herdsman of said cattle--but he's just a Trojan farm-worker, so doesn't really count). In any case, still believing that he had, in fact, killed his fellow Greeks, Aias is overcome with remorse, which drives him to suicide. In his poetry, Sophocles makes some rather elegant puns on "Aias, whose very name speaks mourning!" ("Ai! Ai!")

So, Professor Lyons, do I pass?

*ColgatePalmolive manufactures several different varieties of Ajax¬Æ cleanser: Ajax¬Æ Powder Cleanser, Ajax¬Æ Ultra Citrus Scent +Salt, etc.: a well stocked grocery or hardware store will stock many Aiantes¬Æ.

Since a lot of commenters found this one easy, I thought I'd add to my thoughts from a few days ago about what makes an "easy" puzzle. Someone suggested I check out XWstats.com for more detailed crossword stats, and I highly recommend it for stats nerds. What I discovered using that site is that my "average" puzzle time for each day is usually pretty close to my 75% solve time (which I assume is the time I finish 75% of the puzzles faster than, basically a 75th percentile). So if you are like me, if you finish below your average time, you might still finish more than half the puzzles faster than that time. We still don't get a median finish time for our own puzzles on XW stats, but it's a good bet that your median time is faster than your average time. 

XWstats seems to bear out the idea that this was a relatively easy Friday, with 74% of solvers finishing faster than their Friday average and 40% solving "much faster." 

For me, however, this was not the case. I was right on my 75% solve time, so I've solved 75% of Fridays faster than this one. Either way, I enjoyed the puzzle, and the streak lives on!

On a related note, General Joe Hooker and his troops were stationed in D.C. during the Civil War, and the ladies of the evening that entertained his men were known as "Hooker's Brigade," as Fightin' Joe reportedly turned a blind eye to the activity. (The popular myth that this was the origin of the term "hooker" has been proven false, but it was fun to believe it.}

@Andrzej "two if by sea" is from the American Revolution - it's part of the phrase "one if by land and two if by sea", the number of lanterns that would be shown in a church steeple when it became clear what route the British would take to invade Boston. 

As for Ind - it's the abbreviation for Independent, an option American voters have for registering to vote but not declaring a party affiliation. Ind voters typically* aren't allowed to vote in primary elections (generally held in spring months), since the ballots provided in those elections are for party members to choose among their candidates for going to the general election (held in November).  
* this may vary by state, I'm not sure.

Hope that helps!

@Peter C. 

The infield flu rule is very reasonable.  Your description of it sounds quite wrong.

Suppose a runner is on first base.  If there is a high fly in the infield, the runner can't run because he can't leave until the ball is caught.  If he did, when the ball is caught, it can be thrown to first base and the runner is out.  That's two outs, the batter and the runner.  

Without the infield fly rule, the fielder can simply drop the ball.  No outs yet.  Then he can throw the ball to second, which is a force out on the runner.  Then the second baseman can throw it to first to try to throw the runner out.  That would be the second out.

So an infield fly with a man on first could very easily be turned into two out, instead of just one.  So the infield fly rule is the batter is automatically out, so the fielding team can only get one out.

It takes a long time to describe and explain, but it is perfectly reasonable to have the infield fly rule when there are base runners that are forced to advance on a batted ball.

@Francis No, this is not correct. If there is just a runner on first, there is no infield fly rule in effect, because none is needed. Should a fielder allow the ball to fall, he can indeed throw to second and get the force. But any well-trained batter runs immediately after hitting the ball, and so easily reaches first base before the throw from second, so no double-play.

Long ago, when I was a clever second baseman, I would sometimes intentionally allow a ball to drop in the setting, but only if the batter was a much slower base runner than the runner currently on first. That would replace a fast runner with a slow one, which is good strategy.

@Xword Junkie 

Yeah, you're right.  Thanks for setting me straight.  I still seems to me that if *should* apply if there is a runner on first.

The reason is this.  The infielder can catch the ball and there is one out and still one on at first.

However, if he purposely drops the ball, he'll absolutely be able to get the man on first before he can get to second.  They *might* be able to get the batter getting to first as well.

So dropping the ball is a sure one out, and a possible two out.  Catching it is only a single out.

So I guess you're right.  All this time the infield fly rule made sense to me.  Now all of a sudden it doesn't.
